title: Commands
text:
Commands
Project scripts (via uv run) you can advertise to contributors and maintainers.








Command
Purpose
When to use




uv run trunk-build
Build every graft listed in grafts.yaml and refresh navigation.
Regular builds in CI or before publishing.


uv run trunk-lock
Regenerate grafts.lock after successful builds.
After trunk-build to persist the manifest.


uv run graft-new <name>
Create a new graft branch from the template.
Onboard a new section/chapter owner.


uv run graft-get <name>
Ensure a worktree exists locally for a graft branch.
When resuming work on an existing graft.


uv run graft-build --branch <name>
Build a single graft branch.
Local iteration on one section.


uv run graft-cleanup-orphans
Remove .grafts/* directories no longer registered as worktrees.
Repo hygiene if worktrees drift.




Add your own helper scripts here, or link to CI workflows that run these commands.

title: Glossary
text:
Glossary

Graft: A git branch containing Quarto content that will be mounted into the trunk site.
Trunk: The main branch that controls grafts.yaml, runs builds, and publishes.
Worktree: A checked-out view of a branch living under .grafts/<name>, keeping contributor work isolated.
Export: The rendered output from a graft branch under docs/grafts__/.

title: Quarto Graft
text:
Compose a single Quarto site from branch-scoped worktrees.
Quarto Graft lets contributors build chapters, sections, or full sub-sites in isolated git branches and worktrees while the trunk assembles everything into one Quarto website. Think multi-author books, research collectives, internal docs, or any workflow where content evolves independently but publishes centrally.



Traditional collaboration forces everyone into main, producing merge conflicts, shared heavy deps, and a single project shape. Quarto Graft flips that:

Each contributor owns one branch = one self-contained chapter/section with its own language, env, and runtime.
The trunk never executes contributor code; it only ingests rendered artifacts, keeping main fast and stable.
Broken branches don’t block the site: last-good fallbacks keep content online with visible warnings.






Ready-to-publish Quarto scaffold (navbar, sidebar, favicon, footer, search, GitHub links).
Branch-grafting build system using git worktrees + uv and auto navigation updates.
Clean contributor workflow: no cross-branch conflicts or shared dependency coupling; full local preview per branch.
Failure handling: last-good fallbacks and visible broken-branch stubs.






Declare grafts

# grafts.yaml
branches:
  - { name: python-template, branch: graft/python-template }
  - { name: markdown-template, branch: graft/markdown-template }

Each graft lives in its own branch

git switch graft/python-template
git switch -c graft/markdown-template

Contributors work in isolation


Their branch carries its own docs/, _quarto.yaml, Makefile, uv env.
Local preview:

make preview

Trunk assembles everything

uv run trunk-build
This exports each graft via a worktree under .grafts/<name>, copies rendered content into docs/grafts__/<name>/, and refreshes navigation automatically.

Main site publishes

quarto render docs --no-execute




git clone <repo>
uv sync
uv run trunk-build
quarto render docs --no-execute
quarto preview docs
You’ll see all grafted chapters in one site.







Without Graft
With Graft




Merge conflicts
No cross-branch conflicts


Shared Python/R deps
Independent per-branch envs


Broken builds block everyone
Fallback to last-good


PR noise for content
One clean PR per chapter


Slow monorepo rendering
Trunk never executes heavy code








Multi-author books and research publications
Quant/science teams and education platforms
Internal documentation portals

Not ideal for single-author blogs, live-edit-in-main workflows, or projects without basic git discipline.




main/
├── docs/                 # main website
│   ├── index.qmd
│   ├── appendix/
│   └── grafts__/         # auto-generated graft content
├── grafts.yaml
├── .grafts/              # local worktrees
├── src/quarto_graft/     # tooling
Each graft branch carries its own:
docs/
_quarto.yaml
Makefile
pyproject.toml







Touch only your graft branch.
Do not merge into template branches.
Typical loop:

git switch -c my-chapter
make preview
git push




Own main and any template branches.
Control grafts.yaml, site branding, and publishing.
Run trunk builds and publishing pipelines.

Optional content signing/verification
Per-branch access control

title: Workflow overview
text:
Quarto Graft keeps contributors in small, safe branches while the trunk curates a single site.



Trunk maintainers own grafts.yaml, run builds, and publish.
Contributors work only in their graft branch and never merge back; their content is pulled in by the trunk.





Create a graft branch (or use uv run graft-new <name>).
Develop docs inside the branch in a git worktree under .grafts/<name>.
Export with uv run graft-build --branch <name> or let uv run trunk-build do it for all branches.
Assemble: the trunk writes outputs to docs/grafts__/<name>/... and refreshes the sidebar placeholder.
Publish from docs/_site.





Worktrees keep uncommitted work isolated from main.
Navigation updates happen automatically after each build.
Cleaning graft worktrees is safe-guarded; make clean-grafts will refuse to delete dirty worktrees.

Use this page to explain your team’s review rules, branch protection, or CI steps.

title: Overview
text:
Welcome to the python-template graft. This starter shows how to ship a small Python package and surface it in Quarto content (including notebooks).



uv-managed project with a package at src/python_template/
Quarto site with navbar/sidebar and a demo notebook
Simple greet helper exported from the package




uv sync
uv run quarto render docs --no-execute
Then open _site/index.html or run make preview.



from python_template import greet
greet("Quarto")
See notebook.ipynb for a runnable example.

title: Getting started
text:
Set up the scaffold locally, render it once, and you’re ready to graft branch docs.



Git with worktree support.
Quarto CLI installed.
Python 3.10+ with uv (used for the project scripts).




uv venv
uv sync

# Build everything listed in grafts.yaml
uv run trunk-build

# Render the site without executing code cells
uv run quarto render docs --no-execute




Create a gh-pages branch (or the host you prefer).
Point your Pages settings at docs/_site.
Render locally or in CI, then push the contents of _site to gh-pages.





Add real project copy and visuals to these starter pages.
Add ‘grafts’ to grafts.yaml, run uv run trunk-build, and watch them appear under Grafts from branches in the sidebar.
Wire CI to run trunk-build and quarto render on main pushes.
